body:
User rep calculation was doing a full recompute on all your content. As you can imagine, this was problematic for users with lots of content. 

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed. 

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.
title: Made an adjustment to rep computation. TLDR: traded up-to-date-ness for speed

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed. 

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.
post.title: Made an adjustment to rep computation. TLDR: traded up-to-date-ness for speed

body:
Any plans to fix the time it takes for buttons to function? As of now nothing works at all until every element of the page is fully loaded, so if there's an image still loading in the background or something you can't comment, vote, or do anything. It seems the JS either loads last or waits until everything else is finished.

I explained this more in detail here: https://ruqqus.com/post/1as9/most-functions-including-comments-and-voting
body_html:
Any plans to fix the time it takes for buttons to function? As of now nothing works at all until every element of the page is fully loaded, so if there's an image still loading in the background or something you can't comment, vote, or do anything. It seems the JS either loads last or waits until everything else is finished.

I explained this more in detail here: https://ruqqus.com/post/1as9/most-functions-including-comments-and-voting

body:
No one is a mind reader. Out of frustration, which is understandable and which I share, you're imputing motives to them without any basis. Given that this site is still in beta, I think it's a whole lot more likely that they are frantically working on the issues and don't have a lot of time for explanations -- especially seeing as how we're talking about computer code, which is *extremely* hard to explain in everyday English to non-techies, and which with techies is likely to turn into endless tech talk. Not to mention that nothing is more boring than tech talk.

In my other career as a financial analyst who specialized in high-speed data transmission in the local access section of the telecom network, I am very familiar with how much time it takes to untangle technical issues for non-specialists. As irritated as I am, I'm inclined to call forth some reserves of patience right now. Might as well, 'cause there's nothing anyone can do from the sidelines anyway.

Given that this site is still in beta, I think it's a whole lot more likely that they are frantically working on the issues and don't have a lot of time for explanations -- especially seeing as how we're talking about computer code, which is *extremely* hard to explain in everyday English to non-techies, and which with techies is likely to turn into endless tech talk. Not to mention that nothing is more boring than tech talk.

In my other career as a financial analyst who specialized in high-speed data transmission in the local access section of the telecom network, I am very familiar with how much time it takes to untangle technical issues for non-specialists. As irritated as I am, I'm inclined to call forth some reserves of patience right now. Might as well, 'cause there's nothing anyone can do from the sidelines anyway.

post.body:
User rep calculation was doing a full recompute on all your content. As you can imagine, this was problematic for users with lots of content. 

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed. 

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.

parent.body:
Any plans to fix the time it takes for buttons to function? As of now nothing works at all until every element of the page is fully loaded, so if there's an image still loading in the background or something you can't comment, vote, or do anything. body: There are 3 admins. Obviously they can't answer every single thing, but they specifically refuse to discuss that subject (at least two of them won't) except with specific people. They do have the time to tell people "we don't want your input" and troll those threads, plus they do respond to other subjects, so I would think time isn't the only factor at play here. I think the problem is they incorrectly view complaints as people whining and hating on them rather than trying to correct mistakes and improve the site, so they get offended by it. I wish they could see that's not usually the case.

post.body:
User rep calculation was doing a full recompute on all your content. As you can imagine, this was problematic for users with lots of content. 

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed. 

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.

guild.name: Ruqqus

post.body:
User rep calculation was doing a full recompute on all your content. As you can imagine, this was problematic for users with lots of content. 

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed. 

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.
post.body_html:
User rep calculation was doing a full recompute on all your content. As you can imagine, this was problematic for users with lots of content.

I adjusted rep to make use of stored, pre-computed content score values. This increases performance, at the cost of not having the most up-to-date figures displayed.

In theory, nobody should lose any rep; more recent votes will just take a while to be reflected in the final tally.
post.title: Made an adjustment to rep computation. TLDR: traded up-to-date-ness for speed
